discussion.content: Wouldn't it be C? C makes more sense since D would imply that without a license, users wouldn't be able to access the cloud applications?
Licenses are not related to this issue it should be C. If it is license issue it should say license expired or not able to access at all
"The cloud provider has grown exponentially", this statement is vague. it may means "the infrastructure has grown exponentially" or "it has more customers". I thinks it is the former. so D

you have to maintain the application as it grows since everyone is using the same application and fighting for the same resources. there's a balance that needs to be kept in check or else performance issues will show up.

https://www.metricfire.com/blog/single-tenant-cloud-vs-multi-tenant-cloud/

C.
D is the right answer, C is wrong because in SaaS yo don't have control over the infrastructure.

comments.content: You dont have control but the CSP is. So.... "C. The CSP did not keep up with the growth and the appropriate supporting infrastructure." seems to be the answer

choices.A: The SSL certificate used by the SaaS provider has expired and is no longer valid.
choices.C: The CSP did not keep up with the growth and the appropriate supporting infrastructure.
choices.D: The licensing limit has been exceeded on the SaaS-based, multitenant application server.
choices.B: Some of the new tenants are not from the financial industry and are causing data integrity issues.

questions.question_text:
It is taking an unusually long time for a financial division to run monthly reports on its SaaS-based, multitenant application. The cloud provider has grown exponentially, and more financial industry clients have moved their processing to the SaaS provider.
Which of the following is the MOST probable cause of the issue?

discussion.content: if A need to be correct it need to be something like skype for business service's federation setting

The logical answer will be The provider is having issues with the public IPs.

Going with B.

questions.question_text:
A mobile subscriber is experiencing random limited-service outages. Customers report being unable to make calls or browse. The service provider management console is not showing any alarms, errors, or critical logs, but does show a large number of connection request failures.
Which of the following could be the problem?

A private cloud is using the iSCSI protocol for connection from storage to hypervisors. This connection is not encrypted currently, and the systems administrator is tasked with enabling on-the-fly encryption.
Which of the following technologies should the administrator use?

discussion.content: PKI is about certificates, not straight up encryption. I would think answer is B.
this question is about "on-the-fly encryption", about disk. similar to bitlocker protected disk. the answer is A

Since iSCSI uses the IP protocol, it therefore relies on IP security protocols. Unfortunately, basic IP transmissions lack security, allowing anyone with the know how and inclination to intercept or modify IP communications. One of the more popular methods used for securing IP communications is the IP Security Protocol (IPSec). IPSec is an IP layer-based security protocol, which is in contrast to other security protocols like SSL that operate at the application layer of the OSI model.
Isn't on-the-fly encryption for data at rest? In that case I think D is correct since it refers to Logical Unit Number encrypting
Correct. "By joining together the clients, SAN server, and storage on a Fibre Channel network, the SAN volumes appear and perform as if it were a directly connected hard drive."

questions.question_text: When designing a new private cloud platform, a cloud engineer wants to make sure the new hypervisor can be configured as fast as possible by cloning the OS from the other hypervisor. The engineer does not want to use local drives for the hypervisors. Which of the following storage types would BEST suit the engineer's needs?

comments.content: Actually the answer is B, due to air gaps
I would say it is D. If the control system is also on Cloud, they would need a very high speed connection to use the control system. Because the system is no longer on prem.
No way, Network broadband access is not a problem, the security of a ICS it is. Always you can pay more for broadband like other resources. The correct answer is B.

questions.question_text:
A rural manufacturing company wants to move all IT services, including the industrial control systems, to the cloud.
Given this scenario, which of the following cloud services elements would be a challenge to the deployment?
